name: Planar Portals
description: A portal is a stationary, interplanar connection that links a specific location on one plane of existence to a specific location on another. Some portals function like doorways, appearing as a clear window or a fog-shrouded passage, and interplanar travel is as simple as moving through the portal. Other portals are locations—circles of standing stones, soaring towers, sailing ships, or even whole towns—that exist on multiple planes at once or flicker from one plane to another. Some are vortices, joining an Elemental Plane with a very similar location on the Material Plane, such as a swirling pool of magma in the heart of a volcano (leading to the Plane of Fire) or a maelstrom in the depths of the ocean (leading to the Plane of Water). Passing through a planar portal can be the simplest way to travel from the Material Plane to a desired location on another plane. Often, though, a portal presents an adventure in itself. First, the adventurers must find a portal that leads where they want to go. Most portals exist in distant locations, and a portal's location often has thematic similarities to the plane it leads to. Second, portals often have guardians charged with ensuring that certain creatures don't pass through. A portal's guardian is typically a powerful magical creature, such as a djinni, a sphinx, a titan, or an inhabitant of the portal's destination plane. Finally, most portals aren't open all the time, but open only in particular situations or when a certain requirement is met.
shortDescription: Stationary interplanar connections linking specific locations on different planes, often requiring special conditions to open and guarded by powerful creatures.
flavorText: A portal to Mount Celestia might be located on a mountain peak. The city of Sigil above the Outlands is known as the City of Doors because it features an overwhelming number of item-keyed portals.
rulesAsWritten: A portal is a stationary, interplanar connection that links a specific location on one plane of existence to a specific location on another. Some portals function like doorways, appearing as a clear window or a fog-shrouded passage, and interplanar travel is as simple as moving through the portal. Other portals are locations—circles of standing stones, soaring towers, sailing ships, or even whole towns—that exist on multiple planes at once or flicker from one plane to another. Some are vortices, joining an Elemental Plane with a very similar location on the Material Plane. Most portals exist in distant locations, and a portal's location often has thematic similarities to the plane it leads to. Portals often have guardians charged with ensuring that certain creatures don't pass through. A portal's guardian is typically a powerful magical creature, such as a djinni, a sphinx, a titan, or an inhabitant of the portal's destination plane. Most portals aren't open all the time, but open only in particular situations or when a certain requirement is met. A portal can have any requirement, but the most common are: Command, Key Item, Random, Situation, and Time.

applicationLogic.name: Portal Types
applicationLogic.description: Portals come in three general forms: doorway portals (appearing as clear windows or fog-shrouded passages where interplanar travel is as simple as moving through), location portals (circles of standing stones, soaring towers, sailing ships, or whole towns that exist on multiple planes at once or flicker between planes), and vortex portals (joining an Elemental Plane with a very similar location on the Material Plane, such as a swirling pool of magma leading to the Plane of Fire or a maelstrom in the ocean leading to the Plane of Water).

effects.description: A portal is a stationary, interplanar connection that links a specific location on one plane of existence to a specific location on another. Passing through a planar portal transports the traveler from one plane to another.
effects.mechanicalNote: Portals are stationary and connect fixed locations. Three forms exist: doorway (simple passage), location (exists on multiple planes or flickers), and vortex (elemental connection to similar Material Plane location).

applicationLogic.name: Portal Location Thematic Similarity
applicationLogic.description: Most portals exist in distant locations, and a portal's location often has thematic similarities to the plane it leads to. For example, a portal to Mount Celestia might be located on a mountain peak.

effects.description: A portal's physical location on the origin plane often shares thematic similarities with the destination plane it connects to.
effects.mechanicalNote: DM guidance for placing portals: the location should thematically echo the destination plane.

applicationLogic.name: Portal Guardians
applicationLogic.description: Portals often have guardians charged with ensuring that certain creatures don't pass through. A portal's guardian is typically a powerful magical creature, such as a djinni, a sphinx, a titan, or an inhabitant of the portal's destination plane.

effects.description: Portals often have guardians—powerful magical creatures such as djinn, sphinxes, titans, or inhabitants of the destination plane—that control which creatures may pass through.
effects.mechanicalNote: Guardian creatures are typically powerful magical beings. They enforce access restrictions on the portal.

applicationLogic.name: Command Requirement
applicationLogic.description: The portal functions only if a particular command is given. A command is usually a word that can be invoked in any language (including a signed language). Sometimes the command must be given as a character passes through the portal (which is otherwise a mundane doorway, window, or similar opening). Other portals open when the command is given within 15 feet of themselves, and they remain open for 1d12 minutes.

trigger.condition: A creature speaks or signs the correct command word

effects.description: Command-keyed portals require a specific word or phrase to activate. The command can be spoken in any language including signed language. Some require the command while passing through (otherwise appearing as a mundane opening). Others open when the command is given within 15 feet and remain open for 1d12 minutes.
effects.mechanicalNote: Activation range: while passing through OR within 15 feet. Duration when opened at range: 1d12 minutes. Command is language-agnostic.

applicationLogic.name: Key Item Requirement
applicationLogic.description: The portal functions if the traveler carries a particular object; the item acts much like a key to a door. This item can be a common object or a particular one created for that portal. The city of Sigil above the Outlands is known as the City of Doors because it features an overwhelming number of such item-keyed portals.

trigger.condition: A creature carrying the required key item approaches or enters the portal

effects.description: Item-keyed portals require the traveler to carry a particular object to function. The key item can be a common everyday object or one specifically created for that portal. Sigil, the City of Doors, is renowned for its overwhelming number of item-keyed portals.
effects.mechanicalNote: The traveler must be carrying the required item. Item can be common or purpose-made.

applicationLogic.name: Random Requirement
applicationLogic.description: The portal functions for a random period, then shuts down for a similarly random duration. Typically, such a portal allows 1d6 + 6 travelers to pass through, then closes for 1d6 days.

trigger.condition: The portal randomly activates according to its cycle

effects.description: Random-keyed portals activate and deactivate on an unpredictable cycle. Typically allows 1d6 + 6 travelers to pass through before closing, then remains closed for 1d6 days.
effects.mechanicalNote: Traveler capacity per activation: 1d6 + 6 (typical range 7-12). Closure duration: 1d6 days (typical range 1-6 days).

applicationLogic.name: Situation Requirement
applicationLogic.description: The portal functions only if a particular condition is met. A situation-keyed portal might open on a clear night, when it rains, or when a certain spell is cast in its vicinity.

trigger.condition: A specific environmental or magical condition is met

effects.description: Situation-keyed portals activate only when a particular environmental or magical condition is met, such as a clear night, rainfall, or a certain spell being cast in the portal's vicinity.
effects.mechanicalNote: Activation is conditional on environmental state or magical trigger. Examples: clear night, rain, specific spell cast nearby.

applicationLogic.name: Time Requirement
applicationLogic.description: The portal functions only at particular times on the Material Plane: during a full moon, during the spring equinox or winter solstice, or when the stars are in certain positions. Once it opens, such a portal remains open for a limited time, such as for 3 days following the full moon, for 1 hour, or for 10 minutes.

trigger.condition: A specific celestial or calendrical time is reached

effects.description: Time-keyed portals activate only at particular times: during a full moon, the spring equinox, winter solstice, or when stars reach certain positions. Once open, the portal remains active for a limited duration such as 3 days following the full moon, 1 hour, or 10 minutes.
effects.mechanicalNote: Activation tied to celestial/calendrical events. Duration examples: 3 days, 1 hour, or 10 minutes after activation trigger.

applicationLogic.name: Fey Crossings (Portal Variant)
applicationLogic.description: Fey crossings are places of mystery and beauty on the Material Plane that have a near-perfect mirror in the Feywild, creating a portal where the two planes touch. A traveler passes through a fey crossing by entering a clearing, wading into a pool, passing into a circle of mushrooms, or crawling under the trunk of a tree. Like other portals, most fey crossings open infrequently—during a full moon, on the dawn of a particular day, or for someone carrying a certain type of item. A fey crossing can be closed permanently if the land on either side is dramatically altered.

trigger.condition: A creature enters a fey crossing location when it is active

effects.description: Fey crossings are natural portals between the Material Plane and the Feywild at locations with near-perfect mirrors on both planes. They open infrequently based on conditions (full moon, specific dawn, carrying certain items). A fey crossing can be permanently closed if the land on either side is dramatically altered (e.g., building a castle over the clearing).
effects.mechanicalNote: Natural portal variant specific to Material Plane/Feywild boundary. Can be permanently destroyed by dramatic alteration of terrain on either side.

applicationLogic.name: Shadow Crossings (Portal Variant)
applicationLogic.description: Shadow crossings are locations where the veil between the Material Plane and the Shadowfell is so thin that creatures can pass from one plane to the other. They form in gloomy places where spirits or the stench of death lingers, such as battlefields, graveyards, and tombs. They manifest only in darkness, closing as soon as they feel light's kiss.

trigger.condition: A creature enters a shadow crossing location while it is in darkness

effects.description: Shadow crossings are natural portals between the Material Plane and the Shadowfell that form in gloomy places associated with death (battlefields, graveyards, tombs). They manifest only in darkness and close immediately when exposed to light.
effects.mechanicalNote: Natural portal variant specific to Material Plane/Shadowfell boundary. Requires darkness to function; any light closes the crossing.

applicationLogic.name: Astral Color Pools (Portal Variant)
applicationLogic.description: Color pools are gateways in the Astral Plane appearing as two-dimensional pools of rippling colors, 1d6 × 10 feet in diameter. Their colors are understood rather than seen by the Astral self. They connect the Astral Plane to the Outer Planes, Inner Planes, Ethereal Plane, and Material Plane, identifiable by their color.

trigger.condition: A creature on the Astral Plane locates and enters a color pool

effects.description: Color pools are two-dimensional portals on the Astral Plane appearing as pools of rippling color. Each pool is 1d6 × 10 feet in diameter (range 10-60 feet). Colors indicate destination: Amethyst (Abyss), Flame red (Acheron), Sapphire blue (Arborea), Saffron (Arcadia), Emerald green (Beastlands), Amber (Bytopia), Olive (Carceri), Orange (Elysium), Spiraling white (Ethereal Plane), Russet (Gehenna), Rust (Hades), Jet black (Limbo), Silver (Material Plane), Diamond blue (Mechanus), Gold (Mount Celestia), Ruby (Nine Hells), Leather brown (Outlands), Magenta (Pandemonium), Indigo (Ysgard).
effects.mechanicalNote: Diameter: 1d6 × 10 feet. Colors are perceived metaphorically by the Astral self, not physical eyes.

applicationLogic.name: Carceri One-Way Portal Restriction
applicationLogic.description: On the prison plane of Carceri, portals and gates that open onto the plane become one-way only. Magical efforts to leave the plane by any spell other than Wish simply fail. Secret passages out exist but are hidden and guarded by traps and deadly monsters.

trigger.condition: A portal connects to or exists on the plane of Carceri

effects.description: Portals and gates that open onto Carceri become one-way only (entry permitted, exit denied). Magical efforts to leave Carceri by any spell other than Wish simply fail. Secret passages out of the plane exist but are hidden and well guarded by traps and deadly monsters. The River Styx provides an extremely dangerous and rare exit route.
effects.mechanicalNote: All portals to Carceri become one-way (inbound only). Only Wish spell can magically bypass this restriction. Ferries on the River Styx leading out are rare and expensive.

applicationLogic.name: Ethereal Curtains (Portal Variant)
applicationLogic.description: In the Deep Ethereal, curtains of vaporous color serve as portals to the Border Ethereal of specific planes. Each curtain is distinguishable by color, texture, and temperature reflecting the nature of the plane beyond.

trigger.condition: A creature in the Deep Ethereal passes through an ethereal curtain

effects.description: Ethereal curtains are vaporous colored portals scattered throughout the Deep Ethereal that lead to the Border Ethereal of specific planes. Colors indicate destination: Turquoise (Material Plane), Dusky gray (Shadowfell), Opalescent (Feywild), Pale blue (Plane of Air), Chestnut (Plane of Earth), Orange (Plane of Fire), Green (Plane of Water), Dark gray (Plane of Ash), Aquamarine (Plane of Ice), Maroon (Plane of Magma), Chocolate (Plane of Ooze). Travel between curtains takes 1d10 × 10 hours regardless of origin and destination.
effects.mechanicalNote: Travel time between curtains: 1d10 × 10 hours (range 10-100 hours). In combat, creatures move at normal speeds.

applicationLogic.name: Nine Hells Portal Restriction
applicationLogic.description: By Asmodeus's orders, no planar portals connect directly to the lower layers of the Nine Hells. The first layer, Avernus, is the arrival point for visitors.

trigger.condition: A portal targets one of the lower layers of the Nine Hells

effects.description: By Asmodeus's decree, no planar portals connect directly to any layer of the Nine Hells below Avernus (the first layer). All visitors must arrive at Avernus and descend through each subsequent layer to reach lower ones. The River Styx is the most expeditious means of descending through the layers.
effects.mechanicalNote: Portal restriction enforced by Asmodeus. Only Avernus (layer 1) is accessible via external portals.

stacking.stackingNote: Multiple portals can exist in the same general area, each functioning independently with its own requirements and destinations. The city of Sigil contains an overwhelming number of portals. The Plain of Infinite Portals (Abyss layer 1) contains gaping craters that are portals to other Abyss layers.

dmNotes: Portals are a primary means of interplanar travel and can serve as adventure hooks. Learning and meeting a portal's requirements can draw characters into further adventures as they chase down a key item, scour old libraries for commands, or consult sages to find the right time to visit the portal. Portal locations should thematically match their destinations. Consider guardians appropriate to the destination plane. The Outlands contains 16 gate-towns, each with a portal to a specific Outer Plane. Sigil, the City of Doors, is the greatest concentration of portals in the multiverse.

commonRulings.question: Are planar portals two-way by default?
commonRulings.ruling: Most planar portals allow travel in both directions between the two locations they connect. However, specific planes can alter this: portals to Carceri become one-way (entry only), and Asmodeus restricts portal access to lower layers of the Nine Hells. Fey crossings and shadow crossings generally work in both directions when active.

commonRulings.question: Can a portal have multiple requirements simultaneously?
commonRulings.ruling: The rules state a portal can have any requirement and list five common types (Command, Key Item, Random, Situation, Time). While the text presents them individually, a DM could combine requirements for a particularly important or well-protected portal.

commonRulings.question: How does one find a portal's command word or key item?
commonRulings.ruling: The rules state that learning and meeting a portal's requirements can draw characters into further adventures as they chase down a key item, scour old libraries for commands, or consult sages to find the right time to visit the portal. The Study action using Intelligence (Arcana) checks to recall lore about planes of existence may help identify portal requirements.

commonRulings.question: What happens if a command-keyed portal's duration of 1d12 minutes expires while creatures are passing through?
commonRulings.ruling: The rules do not specify what happens to creatures mid-transit when a portal closes. This is left to DM adjudication.

commonRulings.question: Can fey crossings and shadow crossings be permanently closed?
commonRulings.ruling: Fey crossings can be closed permanently if the land on either side is dramatically altered, for example if a castle is built over the clearing on the Material Plane. Shadow crossings close whenever exposed to light but the text does not specify a permanent closure mechanism beyond removing the gloomy conditions that create them.
